bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Leonard Wood, November 6, 1925

div1.p: Kean informs Wood that he has read Sullivan's manuscript and Wood's memorandum regarding the work of Gorgas in Cuba. Kean still believes that Wood was responsible for pushing Gorgas into accepting the mosquito theory. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Leonard Wood, November 6, 1925
div1.opener:
November 6, 1925.
Major General Leonard Wood, U.S. Army,
Manila, P.I.
My dear General Wood:
div1.p:
I was much interested to receive from you several
weeks ago a copy of Mr. Mark Sullivan's chapter on Gorgas
with some other papers and your memorandum for Mr. Sullivan
which I was to give to him after going over it and making
any suggestions of corrections which seemed desirable. I
had a talk with Mr. Sullivan over the 'phone and he said he
would come down and see me, get the papers and talk things
over. This was ten days ago and as he has not yet come, I
will call him up again and if he is not able to come, I will
mail him your memorandum together with the copy of the memo-
randum of errors which I have attached to your copy of the
chapter on Gorgas. (He didnt come)

I was very glad to be able to read your memorandum
to him with your estimate of Gorgas' work, with which I
absolutely agree. I want to thank you for the kind and com-
plimentary references to me in the paper. It iswas most impor-
tant that the fact should be brought out clearly that noth-
ing of value could have been accomplished in Cuba without
the sympathetic and invaluable assistance of the military
government. I used to tell Michie that neither our dear
Chief, General Lee, or any other of the Generals in Cuba
would ever have authorized the experiments on human beings
which were necessary to the demonstration of the role of
the mosquito. I was talking with Prof. Wm. C. Welch about
this the other day at lunch. I always had an idea that
Gorgas was so slow in accepting the practical value of Reed's
demonstrations that it was due to your pushing him that he
finally began mosquito work in Havana in March, 1901. I
do not find, however, that this has ever been stated by you
or anyone else.*

p.add:
* Since this was written Gen. Frank R. McCoy has written
me that it was true.

div1.p:
I have seen McCoy once or twice. He is now very
busy, as you know, being a member of the Mitchell Court
Martial which is occupying a great deal of space in the
newspapers these days.

With best wishes and cordial regards to Mrs. Wood,
I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired,
Editor.
JRK/W
